title: R43295
content: The Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) tracks major economic indicators such as GDP, personal income, and corporate profits. These indicators are part of BEA's National Economic Accounts. GDP measures the value of goods and services produced by the U.S. economy, including consumer spending, business investment, government spending, and net exports. Personal income is income received by individuals from various sources. Personal income is received by individuals from wages, salaries, dividends, interest, and other forms. Personal outlays consist of personal consumption of goods and services, transfer payments, disposable income, transfer receipts, consumption expenditures, and savings. The Census Bureau collects household income data from various surveys and programs, including the American Community Survey. The American Community Survey (ACS) provides income data on the U.S. population, including median household income, income distribution, and poverty rates. One-year estimates are more current but have a smaller sample size, while five-year estimates are less current but more reliable. The Current Population Survey (CPS) by the Census Bureau and Bureau of Labor Statistics offers estimates on income, poverty, and health insurance coverage. Inflation, tracked by the Consumer Price Index (CPI), measures the overall increase in prices of goods and services in the economy. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) is a BLS program that tracks changes in prices paid by urban consumers for goods and services. BLS provides data on producer prices, import/export prices, and employment cost trends. The CPI program produces monthly data on price changes for goods and services. The Producer Price Indexes (PPIs) measure changes in selling prices received by domestic producers. The International Price Program (IPP) produces Import/Export Price Indexes (MXP). The International Price Program (IPP) produces Import/Export Price Indexes (MXP) containing data on price changes of nonmilitary goods and services traded between the US and the world. The Employment Cost Trends (ECT) produce quarterly indexes measuring labor cost changes and average costs per hour worked. BLS provides national employment data in its monthly news release from household and business surveys, both seasonally and not seasonally adjusted. The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) provides monthly, quarterly, and annual data on employment statistics, labor force data, and productivity measures. They also offer information on labor costs and the value of the U.S. dollar in foreign exchange markets. The Federal Reserve provides an overview on how the foreign exchange value of the dollar relates to its policy. It measures the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar versus various currencies and indices. The data includes interest rates, economic conditions, and indicators since 1948. The Federal Reserve provides an overview of the foreign exchange value of the dollar in relation to its policy, measuring the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar against various currencies and indices. Economic indicators such as interest rates, economic conditions, and reports on personal income and employment are released by several agencies including the Bureau of Economic Analysis, the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the Bureau of the Census, and the Office of Management and Budget. The frequencies of data releases vary by agency and type of economic indicator. A recession is a significant decline in economic activity spread across the economy, lasting more than a few months, normally visible in real GDP, real income, employment, industrial production, and wholesale-retail sales. Recessions are dated by the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER), a private research institute, and are not officially defined by two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth. The NBER defines U.S. Business Cycle Expansions and Contractions, including the most recent recession from December 2007 to June 2009. Various sources provide glossaries and information on economic terms related to GDP, inflation, productivity, the business cycle, unemployment, and personal income in the U.S. economy. The curr_chunk discusses various reports on the U.S. economy, including personal income, saving, global context, slow growth, income distribution, inflation, and monetary policy by different authors.
